Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer violated the duty of fairness by not notifying the applicants that their PRRA application was being reactivated and allowing them to file supplementary submissions
Application_Facts: The applicants' PRRA application was brief due to anticipation of permanent residence approval. After refusal of their permanent residence application, they did not update their PRRA submission. The PRRA decision was made 10 months later, with no new 'novel' evidence presented.
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no unfair treatment found
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the negative PRRA decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed the application, finding no breach of fairness as the applicants had ample opportunity to update their PRRA but failed to do so
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicants were not given a fair chance to update their PRRA application after reactivation
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness under administrative law; duty to disclose novel and significant information post-application where required
Assessment_Factor: Opportunity to provide updated information; presence of novel evidence
Procedural_Issue: Failure to notify applicants of reactivation of PRRA process and allow supplementary submissions
Evidence_Used: Original PRRA application, lack of supplementary submissions, timeline of decisions
Application_Basis: Anticipation of permanent residence approval led to incomplete initial PRRA submission
Evidence_Assessed: No new 'novel' evidence was presented during the 10-month period following permanent residence refusal
Relief_Sought: Quashing of the negative PRRA decision and remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Fairness may require disclosure of novel and significant documents post-application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicants failed to update their PRRA submission despite opportunity
Cause_Description: Applicants sought judicial review after a negative PRRA decision, arguing they were not given a fair chance to update their application
Evidence_Handling: No additional evidence was submitted by applicants during the PRRA reactivation period
Evidence_Issues: Lack of updated or supplementary evidence from applicants
Evidence_Assessment: The court assessed whether new evidence emerged that would trigger a duty to allow supplementation
Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness because applicants had sufficient opportunity to update their application but did not
Decision_Making_Body: PRRA Officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Absence of novel evidence that would necessitate applicant notification and right to respond
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making, particularly in immigration contexts
